page.title: 10Ecology - Conservation
page.content: in 1956 the Isle of May was declared a National Nature Reserve (N.N.R.) by an agreement with the owners (The Northern Lighthouse Board) and the Nature Conservancy Council (N.C.C.),the government body responsible for wildlife conservation in Britain. The island is of national importance for its nesting colonies of seabirds, and for its unique position on the main east coast migration route. Its status as an NNR means that it is scientifically managed to maintain its wildlife intrest. Much research is done by St Andrews and other Universities and the observatory is maned for most of the year by amateur ornathologists. The NCC station a warden on the island during the summer to carry out managemant work and control day visitors who come out from Anstruther and Crail.
